sen.j: 三関（さんげん、さんかん）とは、古代の日本で畿内周辺に設けられた関所の内、特に重視された三つの関の総称。
sen.e: Sangen (or Sankan) is a general term for the three important sekisho (a checkpoint) out of which were established in and around Kinai (five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto) in ancient Japan.

sen.e: Originally it referred to the three checkpoints of Fuwanoseki (Mino Province), Suzukanoseki (Ise Province) and Arachinoseki (Echizen Province), but in the early ninth century Arachinoseki was replaced by Osakanoseki (Omi Province).

sen.j: 三関には鼓吹軍器、すなわち兵器類が常備され、必ず複数の国司四等官が関を守護するため常駐する規定があった。
sen.e: At Sangen some military instruments for kusui (music for military forces in old days), namely weapons, were always provided and there was a rule that at least two kokushi (a provincial officer) of shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks) should always be stationed to defend the seki.
sen.cmt: 「鼓吹（くすい）」は 「鉦鼓(しょうこ)や笛を主楽器とする、古代の軍用の楽」となっています。http://kotobank.jp/word/%E9%BC%93%E5%90%B9 「国司四等官」は「（管理職にあたる）四階級の地方官吏」と解釈しました。http://kotobank.jp/word/%E5%9B%9B%E7%AD%89%E5%AE%98
sen.e: Sangen were always provided with some military instruments and weapons, and there was a rule that at least two kokushi (a provincial officer) of shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks) should always be stationed to defend the seki.

sen.j: この常駐四等官は城主とよばれ、非常事態に備えていた。
sen.e: This shitokan officer stationed was called a castellan and prepared for emergencies.

sen.j: 非常事態が発生すると、朝廷は三関に固関使（こげんし）を派遣する。
sen.e: When a state of emergency occurred, Chotei (Imperial Court) dispatched Kogenshi (a closer of a checkpoint who was dispatched in case of emergency) to Sangen.

sen.e: On this occasion Kogenshi was given a left half of a tally called Kankei (a tally used by military forces when they passed through Sangen in case of emergency) which was kept by Kurazukasa (a public office dealing with tallies for Sangen, clothes of Emperor and Empress, and so on) and compared it at Sangen with a right half which had been kept by Kokushu (head of provincial governors).
